rect.title: 9.5; In order to search the distributed index the query is sent; null

g.text: In order to search the distributed index the query is sent

rect.title: 9.5; from a client to one of the computers in the MPI cluster,; null

g.text: from a client to one of the computers in the MPI cluster,

rect.title: 9.5; which we call the master server (see Fig. 13). By convention; null

g.text: which we call the master server (see Fig. 13). By convention

rect.title: 9.5; the master server is the process with rank 0 in the MPI clus-; null

g.text: the master server is the process with rank 0 in the MPI clus-

rect.title: 9.5; ter, however any process in the MPI cluster can play the; null

g.text: ter, however any process in the MPI cluster can play the

rect.title: 9.5; role of master server.; null

g.text: role of master server.

rect.title: 9.5; The master server broadcasts the query to all of the pro-; null

g.text: The master server broadcasts the query to all of the pro-

rect.title: 9.5; cesses in the cluster and then each process can run the near-; null

g.text: cesses in the cluster and then each process can run the near-

rect.title: 9.5; est neighbor matching in parallel on its own fraction of the; null

g.text: est neighbor matching in parallel on its own fraction of the

rect.title: 9.5; data. When the search is complete an MPI reduce operation; null

g.text: data. When the search is complete an MPI reduce operation

rect.title: 9.5; is used to merge the results back to the master process and; null

g.text: is used to merge the results back to the master process and

rect.title: 9.5; the ﬁnal result is returned to the client.; null

g.text: the ﬁnal result is returned to the client.

rect.title: 9.5; The master server is not a bottleneck when merging the; null

g.text: The master server is not a bottleneck when merging the

rect.title: 9.5; results. The MPI reduce operation is also distributed, as the; null

g.text: results. The MPI reduce operation is also distributed, as the

rect.title: 9.5; partial results are merged two by two in a hierarchical fash-; null

g.text: partial results are merged two by two in a hierarchical fash-

rect.title: 9.5; ion from the servers in the cluster to the master server.; null

g.text: ion from the servers in the cluster to the master server.

rect.title: 9.5; Additionally, the merge operation is very efﬁcient, since the; null

g.text: Additionally, the merge operation is very efﬁcient, since the

rect.title: 9.5; distances between the query and the neighbors don’t have; null

g.text: distances between the query and the neighbors don’t have

rect.title: 9.5; to be re-computed as they are returned by the nearest neigh-; null

g.text: to be re-computed as they are returned by the nearest neigh-

rect.title: 9.5; bor search operations on each server.; null

g.text: bor search operations on each server.

rect.title: 9.5; When distributing a large data set for the purpose of near-; null

g.text: When distributing a large data set for the purpose of near-

rect.title: 9.5; est neighbor search we chose to partition the data into multi-; null

g.text: est neighbor search we chose to partition the data into multi-

rect.title: 9.5; ple disjoint subsets and construct independent indexes for; null

g.text: ple disjoint subsets and construct independent indexes for

rect.title: 9.5; each of those subsets. During search the query is broadcast; null

g.text: each of those subsets. During search the query is broadcast

rect.title: 9.5; to all the indexes and each of them performs the nearest; null

g.text: to all the indexes and each of them performs the nearest

rect.title: 9.5; neighbor search within its associated data. In a different; null

g.text: neighbor search within its associated data. In a different

rect.title: 9.5; approach, Aly et al. [58] introduce a distributed k-d tree; null

g.text: approach, Aly et al. [58] introduce a distributed k-d tree

rect.title: 9.5; implementation where they place a root k-d tree on top of all; null

g.text: implementation where they place a root k-d tree on top of all

rect.title: 9.5; the other trees (leaf trees) with the role of selecting a subset; null

g.text: the other trees (leaf trees) with the role of selecting a subset

rect.title: 9.5; of trees to be searched and only send the query to those trees.; null

g.text: of trees to be searched and only send the query to those trees.

rect.title: 9.5; They show the distributed k-d tree has higher throughput; null

g.text: They show the distributed k-d tree has higher throughput

rect.title: 9.5; compared to using independent trees, due to the fact that; null

g.text: compared to using independent trees, due to the fact that

rect.title: 9.5; only a portion of the trees need to be searched by each query.; null

g.text: only a portion of the trees need to be searched by each query.

rect.title: 9.5; The partitioning of the data set into independent subsets,; null

g.text: The partitioning of the data set into independent subsets,

rect.title: 9.5; as described above and implemented in FLANN, has the; null

g.text: as described above and implemented in FLANN, has the

rect.title: 9.5; advantage that it doesn’t depend on the type of index used; null

g.text: advantage that it doesn’t depend on the type of index used

rect.title: 9.5; (randomized kd-trees, priority search k-means tree, hierar-; null

g.text: (randomized kd-trees, priority search k-means tree, hierar-

rect.title: 9.5; chical clustering, LSH) and can be applied to any current or; null

g.text: chical clustering, LSH) and can be applied to any current or

g.text: future nearest neighbor algorithmin FLANN. In the distrib-

rect.title: 9.5; uted k-d tree implementation of [58] the search does not; null

g.text: uted k-d tree implementation of [58] the search does not

rect.title: 9.5; backtrack in the root node, so it is possible that subsets of; null

g.text: backtrack in the root node, so it is possible that subsets of

rect.title: 9.5; the data containing near points are not searched at all if the; null

rect.title: 10.0; 5.2 Evaluation of Distributed Search; null

g.text: 5.2 Evaluation of Distributed Search

rect.title: 9.5; In this section we present several experiments that demon-; null

g.text: In this section we present several experiments that demon-

rect.title: 9.5; strate the effectiveness of the distributed nearest neighbor; null

g.text: strate the effectiveness of the distributed nearest neighbor

rect.title: 9.5; matching framework in FLANN. For these experiments we; null

g.text: matching framework in FLANN. For these experiments we

rect.title: 9.5; have used the 80 million patch data set of [7].; null

g.text: have used the 80 million patch data set of [7].

rect.title: 9.5; In an MPI distributed system it’s possible to run multi-; null

g.text: In an MPI distributed system it’s possible to run multi-

rect.title: 9.5; ple parallel processes on the same machine, the recom-; null

g.text: ple parallel processes on the same machine, the recom-

rect.title: 9.5; mended approach is to run as many processes as CPU; null

g.text: mended approach is to run as many processes as CPU

rect.title: 9.5; cores on the machine. Fig. 14 presents the results of an; null

g.text: cores on the machine. Fig. 14 presents the results of an

rect.title: 9.5; experiment in which we run multiple MPI processes on a; null

g.text: experiment in which we run multiple MPI processes on a

rect.title: 9.5; single machine with eight CPUcores. It can be seen that the; null

g.text: single machine with eight CPUcores. It can be seen that the

rect.title: 9.5; overall performance improves when increasing the num-; null

g.text: overall performance improves when increasing the num-

rect.title: 9.5; ber of processes from 1 to 4, however there is a decrease in; null

g.text: ber of processes from 1 to 4, however there is a decrease in

rect.title: 9.5; performance when moving from four to eight parallel pro-; null

g.text: performance when moving from four to eight parallel pro-

rect.title: 9.5; cesses. This can be explained by the fact that increasing the; null

g.text: cesses. This can be explained by the fact that increasing the

rect.title: 9.5; parallelismon the same machine also increases the number; null

g.text: parallelismon the same machine also increases the number

rect.title: 9.5; of requests to the main memory (since all processes share; null

g.text: of requests to the main memory (since all processes share

rect.title: 9.5; the same main memory), and at some point the bottleneck; null

g.text: the same main memory), and at some point the bottleneck

rect.title: 9.5; moves from the CPU to the memory. Increasing the paral-; null

g.text: moves from the CPU to the memory. Increasing the paral-

rect.title: 9.5; lelism past this point results in decreased performance.; null

g.text: lelism past this point results in decreased performance.

rect.title: 9.5; Fig. 14 also shows the direct se; null

g.text: Fig. 14 also shows the direct se

rect.title: 9.5; arch performance obtained; null

g.text: arch performance obtained

rect.title: 9.5; by using FLANN directly without the MPI layer. As; null

g.text: by using FLANN directly without the MPI layer. As

rect.title: 9.5; expected, the direct search performance is identical to the; null
